title: The Gulag Archipelago
author: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn
reason: Political content deemed anti-government propaganda (Criticism of Soviet Leadership)
legislation: General anti-state propaganda provisions in the Criminal Code of the RSFSR
description: The book documents the structure and history of the Soviet forced labor camp system based on testimonies from survivors along with archival research. It argues the importance of these camps to the Soviet political repression and describes its scale, conditions. and impact.

title: Helen of Troy
author: Margaret George
description: Margaret George’s 2006 novel Helen of Troy presents the tale of Helen, born from Zeus and Queen Leda of Sparta, whose love affair with Paris, aided by Aphrodite, ignites the Trojan War. From Helen’s perspective, the novel explores her life's progression, including her veiled beauty, forced marriage to Menelaus, and the ten-year conflict that ensues from her departure to Troy. The story details Helen’s return to Greece post-war, slowly reconciling with Menelaus and her daughter, Hermione. Episodes of kidnapping and trauma are depicted. (source)

title: Dear Evan Hansen
author: Val Emmich with Steven Levenson, Benj Pasek, and Justin Paul.
publisher: Little, Brown Books for Young Readers
description: Dear Evan Hansen by Val Emmich is a YA novel expanding on the musical, following an anxious high schooler who becomes a social media sensation after falsely claiming to be best friends with Connor Murphy, a classmate who died by suicide. Evan lies to comfort Connor's grieving family, deepening the deception to feel loved, but must eventually face the consequences of his manufactured life.

title: The Handmaid's Tale
author: Margaret Atwood
description: The Handmaid's Tale by Margaret Atwood is a dystopian novel about June (Offred), a woman forced into sexual servitude as a "Handmaid" in the Republic of Gilead, a totalitarian, theonomic state that replaced the U.S.. Following a fertility crisis, fertile women are assigned to elite couples to bear children. Offred navigates brutal oppression, surveillance, and memories of her past life while attempting to maintain her identity and survive. (From Google AI Overview)

title: Cinderella is Dead
author: Kalynn Bayron
description: Cinderella Is Dead by Kalynn Bayron is a YA dystopian retelling where 16-year-old Sophia, living 200 years after Cinderella, rebels against a brutal patriarchy. Girls are forced to participate in annual, mandated balls to find husbands, or face death. Sophia, in love with her best friend, escapes and teams up with a descendant of Cinderella’s stepsisters to overthrow the king.

title: One flew over the Cuckoo's Nest
author: Ken Kesey
description: A mordant, wickedly subversive parable set in a mental ward, the novel chronicles the head-on collision between its hell-raising, life-affirming hero Randle Patrick McMurphy and the totalitarian rule of Big Nurse.

author: George Orwell
description: In a harsh totalitarian future, Winston Smith briefly rebels against a regime that controls thought and history, but is eventually tortured into total loyalty to Big Brother.

title: The Immoralists
author: Chloe Benjamin
reason: Discussion of the AIDS epidemic; LGBTQIA+; Suicide
description: The Immortalists by Chloe Benjamin is a 2018 novel following four Gold siblings—Simon, Klara, Daniel, and Varya—who visit a New York City psychic in 1969 as children and are told the exact dates they will die. The narrative explores how these prophecies shape their lives, choices, and relationships over five decades, blending themes of destiny, free will, and the pursuit of a meaningful life.

title: Satanic Verses
